paragraphs.title: Merchant Categories
paragraphs.text:
%md

The merchant category is an important feature for a fraud prediction model because people tend to follow the same expenditure pattern on each category.

For instance, it is perfectly common to spend US$10 or even US$200 on Food. But it is uncommon to spend US$1000 (to be very explicit). On the other hand,
it is very common for people to spend a lot on healthcare or hotel services.

Categories are stored on the *IRISDemo.BC_MERCH_CATEGORY* table. The column *BC_MERCH_CAT_CODE* is an integer that is used as a feature of our model. 

Let's see what are the categories we have:

msg.data:
The merchant category is an important feature for a fraud prediction model because people tend to follow the same expenditure pattern on each category.

For instance, it is perfectly common to spend US$10 or even US$200 on Food. But it is uncommon to spend US$1000 (to be very explicit). On the other hand,
it is very common for people to spend a lot on healthcare or hotel services.

Categories are stored on the IRISDemo.BC_MERCH_CATEGORY table. The column BC_MERCH_CAT_CODE is an integer that is used as a feature of our model.

Let’s see what are the categories we have:

ID	BC_MERCH_CAT_CODE	BC_MERCH_CAT_DESC
1	12	Transportation
2	4	Health
3	9	Otherservices
4	3	Food
5	6	Hotelservices
6	0	Barsandrestaurants
7	11	Tech
8	10	Sportsandtoys
9	14	Wellnessandbeauty
10	7	Hyper
11	2	Fashion
12	5	Home
13	1	Contents
14	13	Travel
15	8	Leisure

paragraphs.title: Merchants
paragraphs.text:
%md

Merchants are also important for our model. Take the *Food* category for instance. Food on a merchant can be typically more expensive than on another merchant that also is under category food.

So, both the specific merchant AND the merchant's category become important features for our model.

Merchants are on table *IRISDemo.BC_MERCH_ACCOUNT*. The next query will give you a list of merchants, their feature code and their category feature code:

msg.data:
Merchants are also important for our model. Take the Food category for instance. Food on a merchant can be typically more expensive than on another merchant that also is under category food.

So, both the specific merchant AND the merchant’s category become important features for our model.

Merchants are on table IRISDemo.BC_MERCH_ACCOUNT. The next query will give you a list of merchants, their feature code and their category feature code:

paragraphs.text:
%irisjdbc

select BC_ACC_NUMBER, BC_MERCH_CODE, BC_MERCH_CATEGORY->BC_MERCH_CAT_DESC, BC_MERCH_CATEGORY->BC_MERCH_CAT_CODE from IRISDemo.BC_MERCH_ACCOUNT

paragraphs.title: Spark
paragraphs.text:
%md

Up to now, we have been using JDBC to query IRIS. There are other tables on our normalized data lake such as *IRISdemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS*. This table holds
all debit card transactions. 

Let's use Spark to get a dataframe with the first 100 transactions:

msg.data:
Up to now, we have been using JDBC to query IRIS. There are other tables on our normalized data lake such as IRISdemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS. This table holds
all debit card transactions.

Let’s use Spark to get a dataframe with the first 100 transactions:

paragraphs.text:
%md

But that is not pretty... Zeppelin can help us with some magic:

msg.data: But that is not pretty… Zeppelin can help us with some magic:

paragraphs.text:
%r


df <- read.jdbc(url="jdbc:IRIS://datalake:51773/APP", tableName="IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS", partitionColumn="ID", lowerBound=0, upperBound=500000, user="SuperUser", password = "sys")

head(df)

paragraphs.text:
%r

df2 <- selectExpr(df, "cast (BC_TRANS_IS_FRAUD as INTEGER) as IsFraud", "BC_TRANS_AMOUNT as Amount")

df3 <- filter(df2,"IsFraud<>0")

%r {"imageWidth": "400px"}

histStats = histogram(df2, "IsFraud")

require(ggplot2)

ggplot(histStats, aes(x = centroids, y = counts)) +
         geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
         xlab("IsFraud") + ylab("Frequency")

paragraphs.title: Scala
paragraphs.text:
%md
# Scala

We have been using %irisjdbc, %spark.pyspark and %r to use Direct SQL/JDBC, Spark with Python and Spark with R. We can also don't use any % magic and use Scala, the default language of this notebook:

msg.data:
Scala

We have been using %irisjdbc, %spark.pyspark and %spark.r to use Direct SQL/JDBC, Spark with Python and Spark with R. We can also don’t use any % magic and use Scala, the default language of this notebook:

paragraphs.text:
import com.intersystems.spark._

//val df = spark.read.format("iris").option("dbtable","IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS").load().limit(10)
val df = spark.read.iris("IRISDemo.BC_TRANSACTIONS").limit(10)
z.show(df)

msg.data:
import com.intersystems.spark._
df: org.apache.spark.sql.Dataset[org.apache.spark.sql.Row] = [ID: bigint, BC_TRANS_AMOUNT: double ... 11 more fields]

name: 1- Fetching Data from IRIS with SQL, PySpark, Scala and R
